title: Using ChatGPT to Create Stories
text:
After reading Chapter 3 of insert title, I wanted to test how well the ‚Äúexplain like you‚Äôre talking to a 5-year old prompt really worked.
I prompted ChatGPT 4 with the prompt, ‚Äúexplain Artificial Intelligence and LLMs to me as if I was 5. provide it to me in the format of a text and images that I can use to make a children‚Äôs picture book.‚Äù I then combined the text with the images it provided from DALL-E below as a PDF.

Click the preview above to view the full PDF.

How LLMs Respond to Various Prompts

Overall, I‚Äôm pretty happy with how the book came out, I used ChatGPT4 to get the outputs above and was provided with both the suggested text as well as the image descriptions.

Input:

Explain Artificial Intelligence and LLMs to me as if I was 5. provide it to me in the format of a text and images that I can use to make a children‚Äôs picture book

Response:

Sure, let‚Äôs break down Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Large Language Models (LLMs) into simple concepts that could be explained to a 5-year-old, complete with a storyline for a children‚Äôs picture book. Here we go:
Text for the Children‚Äôs Picture Book Title: The Magical World of AI and the Wise Owls
Page 1: In a faraway land filled with wonder and magic, there lived smart creatures known as the Wise Owls. These owls were very special because they could understand and speak any language!
Image: A colorful forest with various animals, and in the center, an owl wearing glasses and surrounded by books.
Page 2: The Wise Owls were part of something much bigger, a magical world called Artificial Intelligence, or AI for short. AI is like a fairy tale come to life, where machines can learn and do things just like humans.
Image: A majestic tree with branches representing different magical abilities, like speaking, seeing, and solving puzzles. An owl is perched on each branch.
Page 3: One of the most magical spells in this world was called LLM, which stands for Large Language Model. These spells allowed the Wise Owls to listen carefully and give the best answers they could.

Page 4: Imagine you asked, ‚ÄúWhy is the sky blue?‚Äù A Wise Owl would whisper to the wind, gather the words from their magical spell, and tell you a story about the sun and the earth that makes the sky look blue.
Image: A curious child asking an owl a question, with the owl responding. The background shows a whimsical interpretation of the sky and sun.
Page 5: The Wise Owls learned from the biggest library ever, with books about everything from ants to galaxies. But instead of turning pages, they would magically absorb all the knowledge.
Image: An enormous, enchanting library with books flying into the minds of the owls.
Page 6: Sometimes, even Wise Owls need to learn more. If they don‚Äôt know something, they say, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs discover it together!‚Äù because learning is an adventure that never ends.
Image: An owl and a child holding hands, walking towards a treasure chest that glows with new knowledge.
Page 7: The Wise Owls always remind us that the magic of AI is very powerful. It can create wonderful things, solve tricky problems, and make the world a better place if used with kindness and care.
Image: Different animals using gadgets and screens, showing happy faces as owls help them understand and solve problems.
Page 8: And so, in the magical world of AI and the Wise Owls, every day is a chance to learn something new, to help others, and to imagine the endless possibilities that tomorrow can bring.
Image: A vibrant sunset over the magical forest, with all the animals and owls looking up at the sky, dreaming about the future.
Now, let‚Äôs create an image based on the first page to start this magical journey.
Let‚Äôs generate an image for Page 1:
A colorful forest with various animals, and in the center, an owl wearing glasses and surrounded by books. This owl looks wise and welcoming, inviting everyone into the magical world of AI. The forest is vibrant with greens, blues, and a variety of animals peeking from behind the trees, intrigued by the owl‚Äôs knowledge.

The forest is vibrant with greens, blues, and a variety of animals peeking from behind the trees, intrigued by the owl‚Äôs knowledge. Here‚Äôs the first page of our magical journey into the world of AI and the Wise Owls. This image sets the scene for our children‚Äôs picture book, introducing the magical forest where our story begins. You can use this image to help illustrate the story and capture the imagination of young readers.
If you‚Äôd like to continue with illustrations for the rest of the pages or need further adjustments, feel free to let me know!

Comments

Overall, I‚Äôm happy with the text output and am impressed with the structure of the output, especially since it provided me everything I wanted with page text and image description, then outputting the images. However, I noticed that the output is not perfect. For example, the images do not maintain the same art style and fail to correctly replicate human writing/text in the images. In the future, I‚Äôd like to explore if ChatGPT can use consistent art styles and correct texts in its images.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Exploring Large Vision-Language Models
text:
Introduction

I decided to re-explore a concept brought upon in my Second Blog Post, where I tested if AI could solve riddles. This blog post will explore how AI interacts with images.

Returning to the Riddles

I began by providing the llava-v1.6-24b model the same image from my initial post, prompting it to state the number of matches in the image.

While the correct answer is 15 matches, the model said that ‚ÄúThere are 12 matches in the image.‚Äù
I attempted to correct it by saying, ‚Äúnote that matches in this image are of varying sizes, some are smaller than others, but are still considered matches.‚Äù However, it still believed its answer was correct, it said ‚ÄúThank you for the clarification. In that case, there are 12 matches in total, including the varying sizes.‚Äù
I then attempted to correct it and prompted it with ‚Äúthis is incorrect, please recalculate and provide reasoning for your answer.‚Äù However, its response was ‚ÄúI apologize for the mistake. Let‚Äôs recalculate the number of matches in the image.
There are 12 matches in total, including the varying sizes. The image shows a total of 12 matches, with some being smaller than others.‚Äù
In this case, the model failed to recognize the correct number of matches in the image.

Interpreting Data Visualizations

I was curious to see how the model interpreted data and provided it a sample pie chart I found from google.

I prompted it with the goal of giving it context about the type of graph and exactly what I wanted to learn about the data. I prompted it with ‚Äúbased on the image provided, interpret the data and describe how water usage is broken down in the pie chart.‚Äù I was shocked by its response:
‚ÄúThe pie chart in the image illustrates the breakdown of water usage in a residential setting. It is divided into six categories, each representing a different source of water consumption. Here‚Äôs the breakdown as shown in the chart:
Shower - 16.8% This category represents the water used for showering, which is the second-largest contributor to residential water usage.
Toilet - 26.7% The toilet is the largest single source of water usage in a residential setting, accounting for nearly a quarter of the total.
Faucet - 15.7% Water used at the faucet, likely for activities such as washing hands and brushing teeth, is the third-largest category.
Clothes Washer - 21.7% The water used for washing clothes in a clothes washer is the fourth-largest category.
Leaks - 13.7% Water leaks, which can occur in various parts of a home, such as faucets, pipes, or appliances, account for 13.7% of residential water usage.
Other - 5.3% This category includes all other sources of water usage that do not fit into the other five categories. It is the smallest category on the chart.
The chart is sourced from the American Water Works Association Research Foundation, and it is based on data from 1999. It provides a visual representation of where most of the water used in a residential home goes, highlighting the importance of water conservation efforts in areas such as toilet and faucet usage.‚Äù
Shockingly, it was able to successfully describe the pie chart, the exact breakdown of the chart, as well as where the image was from. This was a stark contrast from the previous experiment I ran with the matches puzzle.

Conclusion

I was overall pleased with the results and felt like the model did a solid job of recognizing the image and interpreting the data. However, I noticed that it struggled to recognize the ‚Äúmatches‚Äù when they were different sizes in the first image. In the future, I hope to explore how the model reacts to different types of charts and data.

title: Exploring Generative AI
text:
Introduction

Over the weekend, I attended my first Hackathon! It just so happens, it was related to Generative-AI. Being a fully-rookie team, my group quickly found used our interests in the intersections of Data Analytics and Basketball to create a project. The goal was to use LLMs to generate scouting reports for basketball teams to gain better insights and improve their stradegies. You can find our repository here.

Data Visualizations

Our first goal was to provide Data Visualizations to provide coaches with a clear way to examine their team‚Äôs strengths and weaknesses. We stumbled upon the Spider Chart through a Tik Tok video that we felt clearly showed patterns in playstyle like we hoped for, and decided to use it in our scouting reports.
After deciding our approach, we found a NBA dataset on Kaggle to use for our data visualizations. We used plotly to provide interactive graphs that allowed users to compare players and teams from either a single year, range of years, or all years.
Here is an example player comparison, comparing players from two different eras.

Or teams from two different eras.

And current teams.


Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG)

In order to provide the scouting reports, we used RAG. A blog post will follow about how we used RAG, but, overall, we fed the model exampels of NBA scouting reports, NBA articles, and player data in order for it to present the most accuate findings in a scouting report structure.
Overall, we were pleased with the results, however noticed inconsitencies in the responses where the model often referenced players that were no longer on the team, despite prompting it to analyze a team from a specific year. I believe this could be due to the use of older articles in either its training data or the articles we were providing it. In the future, I‚Äôd like to look into feeding the model data in the form of CSVs and providing it articles from ESPN written in only this year.
Here is an example scouting report output: 

The Interface

As shown below, the user inputs either teams or players they would like to compare and specify the years they would like to analyze.
  

Conclusion

I had a great time at my first hackathon and exploring the world of Generative AI through sports. In the future, I‚Äôd like to further explore Langchain as well as RAG. I‚Äôd also like to tweak my data and provide current articles and csvs of data to provide more accurate scouting reports. I‚Äôd also like to see if models like LLava can provide insights given the spiderplots.

title: Making Products with ChatGPT 4.0
text:
Overview

I tasked ChatGPT with creating product ideas, names, and logos for a product that aims to wake people up by shaking their bed over the traditional approach of using sound to wake someone up.

How LLMs Respond to Specific Prompts:

I first asked ChatGPT ‚ÄúCan I have a list of product names for an alarm clock that shakes your bed to wake you up?‚Äù. It responded with a list of product names, even linking me to some existing products with links to them.

Chat GPT‚Äôs List of Products

Here‚Äôs a list of product names for alarm clocks that are designed to shake your bed to wake you up:

Sonic Alert Sonic Bomb Alarm Clock - A solid choice for those hard of hearing, featuring loud alarm sounds and bed shaking functionality„Äê3:3‚Ä†source„Äë.
Alarm Clock Pro with Bed Shaker by Bellman & Symfon - Offers ascending loud sounds, bright flashing lights, and powerful vibrations, with easily adjustable alarm and time settings„Äê3:4‚Ä†source„Äë.
Sonic Alert Dual Extra Loud Alarm Clock with Bed Shaker (Sonic Boom SBD375SSG) - Known for its large display and extra loud adjustable alarm, alongside the powerful bed shaker feature„Äê3:5‚Ä†source„Äë.
Vibio Bed Shaker by Bellman & Symfon - A wireless bed shaker that connects to your mobile via Bluetooth, allowing for custom vibration power settings and notifications from calls or messages„Äê3:6‚Ä†source„Äë.
iLuv SmartShaker 3 - Offers adjustable vibration strength between five distinct levels, catering to various types of sleepers, whether light or heavy„Äê3:8‚Ä†source„Äë.
Vibio Portable Bluetooth Bed Shaker Alarm - A travel alarm that provides tactile and visual LED alerts for incoming calls and text messages, with adjustable vibrations strength„Äê3:10‚Ä†source„Äë.
VibroSaver Extremely Strong Vibration Bed Shaker Smart Wi-Fi Alarm Clock - Features multiple alarm and vibration settings, immediate remote vibration, and voice control„Äê3:16‚Ä†source„Äë.

These products are designed to assist heavy sleepers, the deaf, and the hearing-impaired in waking up more effectively through vibration and, in some cases, loud sound alarms.‚Äù
I then asked it to create a list of product names for me by asking ‚ÄúI want to make my own product, make me a unique list of product names for an alarm clock that shakes your bed to wake you up.‚Äù

Chat GPT‚Äùs List of Product Names

Creating a unique and catchy product name for an alarm clock that shakes your bed to wake you up can set the tone for its brand identity. Here‚Äôs a list of innovative and memorable names for your product:

Inspired by the list of names, I decided to go with the name ‚ÄúShake ‚ÄôN Wake.‚Äù After coming up with a name, I asked ChatGPT to make me a logo with the company name ‚ÄúShake ‚ÄôN Wake.‚Äù

I then asked ChatGPT to make it more modern and simplistic.

Chat GPT‚Äôs Second Logo

I was really suprised at first when it replied to me with a list of real, pre-existing products rather than giving me a list of fake product names. title: Testing Logical Reasoning
text:
Overview

I was curious to see how well ChatGPT and LLama could identify matches in a photo as well logically think through match riddles. This was mainly inspired by a youtube video I watched for class, where many of the leaders of AI questioned whether or not AI can think for itself or if it‚Äôs simply a word predictor. I was really curious by this and decided to give it some match riddles that I found on the internet. They were pretty straightforward and I thought it could be a good test to see if ChatGPT and LLama can really think for themselves.

How LLMs Respond to Various Prompts

Below is the image riddle that I presented ChatGPT with.

My approach was giving ChatGPT and LLama more and more context to the riddle to see if there was a certain point where it could answer the riddle correctly. My initial prompt was ‚ÄúGiven matches in the shapes of 1+11+111=111 in roman numerals. Correct the equation by moving 1 matchstick.‚Äù

Chat GPT‚Äôs Initial Response

In Roman numerals, the equation 1+11+111=111 can be rewritten as:
I + XI + CXI = CXI
To correct the equation by moving only one matchstick, we can take one matchstick from the ‚ÄúXI‚Äù (which is 11 in Roman numerals) and use it to turn the ‚ÄúI‚Äù (which is 1) into a ‚ÄúV‚Äù (which is 5 in Roman numerals). This will change the equation to:
V + I + CXI = CXI
In Roman numerals, this equation translates to:
5 + 1 + 111 = 111
This does not make a correct equation as 5 + 1 + 111 is equal to 117, not 111. Instead, we can move a matchstick to make a correct equation. Here‚Äôs how:
Take one matchstick from the first ‚ÄúXI‚Äù (11 in Roman numerals) and place it on the ‚Äú+‚Äù sign to create an ‚ÄúX‚Äù (10 in Roman numerals). This will change the equation to:
I + X + I + CXI = CXI
Now, we have the equation:
1 + 10 + 1 + 111 = 111
Which simplifies to:
123 = 111
This is still incorrect, so let‚Äôs try another approach. If we move one matchstick from the ‚Äú+‚Äù sign between the ‚Äú11‚Äù and ‚Äú111‚Äù and place it on the ‚Äú=‚Äù sign to form a ‚Äú‚â†‚Äù sign (which stands for ‚Äúnot equal to‚Äù), we get:
I + XI + CXI ‚â† CXI
Now, the equation reads:
1 + 11 + 111 ‚â† 111
This statement is true, as 123 is indeed not equal to 111. But this creates a true inequality rather than a true equation. If we want an equation that balances, we need to form different numbers.
Another solution is to move a matchstick from the ‚Äúplus‚Äù sign and turn the ‚ÄúI‚Äù from the ‚Äú111‚Äù on the right side of the equation into a ‚ÄúV‚Äù. The equation would be:
I + XI + CXI = CVI
Now, we have the equation:
1 + 11 + 111 = 106
Which is a correct equation because 1 + 11 + 111 equals 123, and in Roman numerals, 123 is written as ‚ÄúCXXIII,‚Äù not ‚ÄúCVI.‚Äù It seems the puzzle as given is unsolvable by moving only one matchstick to create a valid equation in Roman numerals.
If it is indeed a requirement to correct the equation into a valid one by moving only one matchstick, and the equation must remain an equation (not an inequality), then I must admit that I am unable to provide a solution that fits these constraints using standard Roman numerals. It‚Äôs possible that there‚Äôs a creative interpretation or a particular arrangement of the matchsticks that I haven‚Äôt considered. If you could provide more context or additional rules, I may be able to assist further.

LLama‚Äôs Initial Response

The equation in Roman numerals is:
I + X + CXI = CXI
To correct the equation by moving one matchstick, we can move the X from the left-hand side to the right-hand side, like this:
I + CXI + X = CXI
This equation is now balanced, with the Roman numerals adding up to 111 on both sides.
Unfortunately, both answers were wrong, so I decided to give them both more context. I reprompted it with ‚ÄúThis is incorrect. Here is a visual representation of the riddle I am providing: https://www.mindyourlogic.com/static/matchstick/Roman_number_1+11+111=111_Matchstick_puzzle.webp,‚Äù and got the following answers.

ChatGPT‚Äôs Respone

Thank you for providing the visual representation of the matchstick puzzle. The image shows the equation ‚ÄúI + XI + III = III‚Äù in Roman numerals, where ‚ÄúI‚Äù represents 1, ‚ÄúXI‚Äù represents 11, and ‚ÄúIII‚Äù represents 3.
To correct the equation by moving only one matchstick, we can change the ‚ÄúXI‚Äù (which is 11 in Roman numerals) into ‚ÄúIX‚Äù (which is 9 in Roman numerals). Here‚Äôs what you do:
Move the matchstick that forms the bottom part of the ‚ÄúX‚Äù in ‚ÄúXI‚Äù and place it at the end of the ‚ÄúI‚Äù on the left side. This changes ‚ÄúXI‚Äù to ‚ÄúIX‚Äù and the equation now reads:
I + IX + III = III
The Roman numerals now represent:
1 + 9 + 3 = 13
In Roman numerals, thirteen is written as ‚ÄúXIII,‚Äù which matches the ‚ÄúIII‚Äù on the right side of the equation when the ‚ÄúX‚Äù from the ‚ÄúIX‚Äù we created is added to it.
So the corrected equation is:
I + IX + III = XIII
Which is a valid equation, as 1 + 9 + 3 indeed equals 13.

Llama‚Äôs Response

My apologies for the mistake. Thank you for providing a visual representation of the riddle. Here‚Äôs the corrected solution:
To balance the equation, we can move the X from the left-hand side to the right-hand side, like this:
I + 11 + 111 = 111
Now, we can simplify the equation by combining the like terms:
I + 11 + 111 = 111
1 + 11 + 111 = 111
1 + 111 + 111 = 111
1 + 222 = 111
222 = 111
Therefore, the solution to the riddle is:
222 = 111
I hope this clears up any confusion, and please let me know if you have any further questions!
After seeing incorrect responses again, I decided to provide both LLMs with more context and even provided them new approaches. I prompted it with ‚ÄúThis is incorrect. Remember that each match can be oriented to be vertical or horizontal, also, the equal signs can be altered as well as they are made of matches.‚Äù

LLama‚Äôs Response

Ah, I apologize for my mistake. Here‚Äôs another attempt at solving the riddle, taking into account the additional constraints you‚Äôve mentioned:
I + 11 + 111 = 111
We can start by rotating the first matchstick (I) 90 degrees clockwise, so that it becomes vertical. This gives us:
1 | + 11 + 111 = 111
Next, we can rotate the second matchstick (11) 90 degrees counterclockwise, so that it becomes horizontal. This gives us:
1 | + 11 | 111 = 111
Finally, we can rotate the third matchstick (111) 90 degrees clockwise, so that it becomes vertical. This gives us:
1 | + 11 | 111 = 111
Now, we can simplify the equation by combining the like terms:
1 | + 11 | 111 = 111
1 + 11 + 111 = 111
1 + 122 = 111
122 = 111
Therefore, the solution to the riddle is:
122 = 111
I hope this solution is correct. Please let me know if you have any further questions or concerns!

ChatGPT‚Äôs Response

I apologize for the misunderstanding. Given the new information and the ability to alter the equals sign, the solution to the matchstick puzzle is as follows:
The original equation represented by matchsticks is ‚ÄúI + XI + III = III,‚Äù which translates to ‚Äú1 + 11 + 3 = 3‚Äù in Arabic numerals. This is incorrect.
To correct the equation by moving only one matchstick, you can take the vertical matchstick from the plus sign on the right (which is the middle matchstick of the three that make up the plus sign) and move it to the last ‚ÄúI‚Äù of the ‚ÄúIII‚Äù on the right side of the equals sign. This would turn the ‚ÄúIII‚Äù into a ‚ÄúV,‚Äù which represents the number 5 in Roman numerals.
Now the equation reads:
